conclusion: Determine the area S of the curved surface of the semi-cylindrical body through which light exits.
Light exits through the curved surface when it is incident at an angle less than the critical angle for total internal reflection.
The critical angle θ_c for total internal reflection is given by Snell's Law: n sin(θ_c) = n_air sin(90°).
With n = 2 and n_air = 1, 2 sin(θ_c) = 1, which gives sin(θ_c) = 1/2.
The critical angle θ_c is arcsin(1/2) = 30°.
Light will exit through the curved surface if the angle of incidence is less than the critical angle θ_c = 30°.
The semi-cylindrical body has a radius R.
The light enters vertically through the rectangular surface.
The angle of incidence θ at the curved surface is the same as the angle from the vertical to the radius at the point of incidence.
The light exits if the angle from the vertical to the radius is less than 30°.
The arc length s of the curved surface through which light exits is given by s = R θ, where θ is in radians.
The range of angles is from -30° to 30°, which is θ = 2 × 30° = 60° = π/3 radians.
The arc length is s = R × π/3.
The area S of the curved surface through which light exits is the product of the arc length and the length L of the cylinder: S = s × L = (R × π/3) × L = π R L/3.
The area S of the part of the cylindrical surface through which light exits is S = π R L/3.
